hanzi-su-wiki:
吾

Значения

Я; наш, мой, свой

Мнемоника

Я как часть семьи, состоящей, минимум, из пяти 五 ртов 口 — мужа, жены, бабушки, дедушки и ребёнка.

purpleculture_info: Pictophonetic: 五 indicates the sound; 口 (mouth) conveys the meaning.
purpleculture_examples:
维吾尔族 [ wéi wú ěr zú ]: Uighur (Uyghur) ethnic group of Xinjiang
支吾 [ zhī wú ]: to resist; to deal with
伊吾 [ yī wú ]: Yiwu county in Kumul prefecture 哈密地区 , Xinjiang
支吾其词 [ zhī wú qí cí ]: (idiom) to talk in a roundabout way to cover up the truth; evasive
吾人 [ wú rén ]: (literary) we; us
purpleculture_tree:
• ⿱ Above to below
    • 五 [ wǔ ] five; surname
    • 口 [ kǒu ] mouth; entrance, gate, opening
heisig_chinese_memo: I have FIVE senses but my favorite one, taste, I (literary) experience with my MOUTH.
heisig_story: There are actually a number of kanji for the word I, but the others tend to be more specific than this one. The key word here should be taken in the general psychological sense of the "perceiving subject." Now the one place in our bodies that all five senses are concentrated in is the head, which has no less than five mouths: 2 nostrils, 2 ears, and 1 mouth. Hence, five mouths = I.
koohiiStory2: I eat five times at day.
WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: I have five things in my mouth and I need them all for me. I own these five things, and I keep them in my mouth so people like you cannot take them from me.
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: What five things would you keep in your mouth to protect them from me? Imagine these five things in your mouth and think of how important they are to you as you taste them on your tongue.
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: Me, personally, I am quite thirsty so I ask for some “waga” (わが). I have five things in my mouth, so it is hard for me to pronounce the word “water”. So it sounds like “waga” when I ask for it. “Coulg I pweash hab sum waga?! I deed waga!!”
WaniKani_Reading_Info: Imagine how you would sound asking for “waga” with your mouth full of five things. You can carry out this experiment in real life if you would like, just be careful not to choke, okay?
Ru_Notes: Сравни: 五 (いつつ、ゴ пять), 悟 (さとる、ゴ постижение)
Ru_trainchinese: wú: (местоим) (книжн.) я, мой, мы, наш
Kanshudo_mnemonic: the five (五) mouths (口) belong to I
chinese_mnemonics_deck__story: I have FIVE senses but my favorite one, taste, I (literary) experience with my MOUTH.
humanum_full_description_en:
Elaboration: The inscriptions from the " mouth ", the sound of " five ", the Mao Gongding from the two " five ", from the mouth. Borrowed as the first-person pronoun. "Shuowen": "I, I, I call myself. Five voices from my mouth." Duan Yucai changed his " title " to "偁", with the note: "The name of each book is wrong."

In the early inscriptions, a vertical stroke was added between the five characters as a decorative pen. The inscriptions were used as first-person pronouns, "Er Ya. "Shigu": "I, I too." Shen Zitagui: "Say to me, I test" I and Wu are used in conjunction, which are self-proclaimed compound words. This is often the case in Bronze inscriptions, and I and Yu are used in conjunction, like Shaoya Sword: "My name is more than my name, and my stomach is a little bit." And pass for " Yu " Mao Gongding: "to Save the Queen is the family dry body," "dry I" that is, "to defend Yu" literature as "Hanyu", " I ", " Yu ", " imperial " homonyms general, expressed Defend, guard. "Zuo Zhuan. "The 26th Year of Xianggong": "Defend Beidi".
humanum_short_description_en: Bronze inscriptions start from the " mouth " to the sound of " five ", and Mao Gongding starts from the second and the " five ", from the mouth. Borrowed as the first-person pronoun.
humanum_full_description:
金文從「口」，「五」聲，毛公鼎從二「五」相疊，從口。借用為第一人稱代詞。《說文》：「吾，我，自稱也。从口五聲。」段玉裁改「稱」為「偁」，注云：「偁各本作稱，誤。」

　　早期金文於五字中間加一豎劃為飾筆，金文用作第一人稱代詞，《爾雅．釋詁》：「吾，我也。」沈子它簋：「卲告朕吾考」朕、吾連用，是自稱複詞，金文多見此例，又有朕、余連用，如少虡劍：「朕余名之，胃之少虡」。又通作「敔」，毛公鼎：「以乃族干吾王身」，「干吾」即「捍敔」，文獻作「捍禦」，「吾」、「敔」、「禦」同音通用，表示捍衛、守衛。《左傳．襄公廿六年》：「扞禦北狄」。
humanum_short_description: 金文從「口」，「五」聲，毛公鼎從二「五」相疊，從口。借用為第一人稱代詞。

金文從「 口 」，「 五 」聲，毛公鼎從二「 五 」相疊，從口。借用為第一人稱代詞。《說文》：「吾，我，自稱也。从口五聲。」段玉裁改「 稱 」為「 偁 」，注云：「偁各本作稱，誤。」 早期金文於五字中間加一豎劃為飾筆，金文用作第一人稱代詞，《爾雅．釋詁》：「吾，我也。」沈子它簋：「卲告朕吾考」朕、吾連用，是自稱複詞，金文多見此例，又有朕、余連用，如少虡劍：「朕余名之，胃之少虡」。又通作「 敔 」，毛公鼎：「以乃族干吾王身」，「干吾」即「捍敔」，文獻作「捍禦」，「 吾 」、「 敔 」、「 禦 」同音通用，表示捍衛、守衛。《左傳．襄公廿六年》：「扞禦北狄」。

In the early inscriptions, a vertical stroke was added between the five characters as a decorative pen. The inscriptions were used as first-person pronouns, "Er Ya. "Shigu": "I, I too." Shen Zitagui: "Say to me, I test" I and Wu are used in conjunction, which are self-proclaimed compound words. This is often the case in Bronze inscriptions, and I and Yu are used in conjunction, like Shaoya Sword: "My name is more than my name, and my stomach is a little bit." And pass for " Yu" Mao Gongding: "to Save the Queen is the family dry body," "dry I" that is, "to defend Yu" literature as "Hanyu", " I", " Yu", " imperial" homonyms general, expressed Defend, guard. 吾
wú

姓。
Iwe

yù

吾字的汉语字典释义

[①]［wú］
［《廣韻》五乎切，平模，疑。］
(1)我，我们。表示第一人称。
(2)抵御。
(3)姓。三国吴有吾粲。见《三国志·吴志》本传。
[②]［yú］
［《集韻》牛居切，平魚，疑。］
(1)见“吾2吾”。
(2)通“虞”。兽名用字。
(3)通“虞”。见“吾2丘”。
(4)通“魚”。参见“吾2山”。
[③]［yá］
［《廣韻》五加切，平麻，疑。］
(1)见“吾3子”。
(2)地名用字。

吾字的英文翻译

◎ 吾
I, we

吾字的康熙字典解释

【丑集上】【口字部】　吾； 康熙笔画：7； 页码：页180第03
〔古文〕?【唐韻】五乎切【集韻】【韻會】【正韻】訛胡切，?音梧。【說文】我自稱也。【爾雅·釋詁】吾，我也。【左傳·桓六年】我張吾三軍，而被吾甲兵。【楚辭·九章註】朱子曰：此篇多以余吾?稱，詳其文意，余平而吾倨也。又【廣韻】御也。執金吾，官名。【前漢·百官公卿表】中尉，秦官，武帝太初元年，更名執金吾。【註】師古曰：金吾，鳥名也，主辟不祥。天子出行，職主先導，以禦非常，故執此鳥之象以名官。又【後漢·百官志】執金吾掌宮外戒司非常水火之事，月三繞行宮外，及主兵器。吾猶禦也。【註】應劭曰：執金革，以禦非常。　又【集韻】棒名。【古今注】金吾，車輻棒也。漢官執金吾，吾，止也，執金革禦非常也，以銅爲之，黃金塗兩末謂之金吾，御史大夫司隷校尉亦得執焉。○按顏應二說，及古今注凡三義，各不相同，今?存之。　又昆吾，國名。【詩·商頌】昆吾夏桀。【箋】已姓。　又地名。【前漢·揚雄傳】武帝廣開上林，南至宜春鼎湖，御宿昆吾。【註】晉灼曰：昆吾，地名，有亭。　又鍾吾，國名。漢爲司吾

["Jiyun" Niu Juqie, Pingyu, doubt. ]

(2) Through "Yu". Use words for animal names.

(4) Through "fish". See "My 2 Mountain".
[③] [yá]
["Guangyun" five plus cut, flat hemp, doubt. ]

(2) Words used in place names.

Radicals: 五, 口  (five, mouth)
Meaning Mnemonic
I have five things in my mouth and I need them all for me. I own these five things, and I keep them in my mouth so people like you cannot take them from me.
What five things would you keep in your mouth to protect them from me? Imagine these five things in your mouth and think of how important they are to you as you taste them on your tongue.
Reading Mnemonic
Me, personally, I am quite thirsty so I ask for some “waga” (わが). I have five things in my mouth, so it is hard for me to pronounce the word “water”. So it sounds like “waga” when I ask for it. “Coulg I pweash hab sum waga?! I deed waga!!”
Imagine how you would sound asking for “waga” with your mouth full of five things. You can carry out this experiment in real life if you would like, just be careful not to choke, okay?
